string-array.name: help_texts
string-array.item:
Substrate is a collection of live wallpapers for Android.
\ 
\ A live wallpaper is a wallpaper which runs in the background of your home screen, displaying a constantly-changing backdrop. This application is a collection of live wallpapers (a.k.a. "screen hacks"), each one displaying a slowly growing pattern which gradually evolves in your home screen.
\ 
\ The hacks collected here are the work of J.Tarbell; to see more of this beautiful work you can visit his web site at http://complexification.net/ . The author of this app is not affiliated with the website or J.Tarbell.
\ 
\ Note that this app only previews the live wallpapers. To actually set one as your wallpaper, see "Installing" below. Also note that the hacks run much faster in this preview than they do as wallpapers, so that you can see how they develop. Live wallpapers run more slowly, as we don't want to flatten your battery or be too distracting.

To set one of these hacks as your wallpaper, you need to install it as follows:
\ • Go to your home screen.
\ • Press the menu key.
\ • Select "Wallpaper", then "Live wallpapers".
\ • Pick your preferred wallpaper.

Within the Substrate application, the device's "menu" button pops up a menu containing a number of options:
\ 
\ • Select hack selects the screen hack to preview in the application.
\ 
\ • Hack preferences pops up the preferences panel for the currently displayed hack. The preferences you select here affect the hack globally, so if it is currently running in your home screen, you can change its settings from here rather than needing to re-install it. See "The Hacks" below for details.
\ 
\ • Help displays this help.
\ 
\ • About displays an about box, with links to the license and the project home page.
\ 
\ • Exit stops the Substrate application. This doesn't affect your wallpaper.

This section provides details on each of the live wallpapers — \"hacks\" — available in this package, including details of the settings available in each hack. There are also some settings which are common to all hacks, as detailed in the next section.
If you would like more information and help with Substrate, or if you want to to report a bug, there are some on-line resources which may be of interest, as described in the following sections.

string-array.name: help_hacks_texts
string-array.item: The following preferences settings are available in all the hacks:\n\ \n\ • Background colour sets the background colour for the hack. White produces a clear, bright rendering; black is more subtle, and may save some battery power on devices with an OLED display.

Substrate is the title hack and inspiration for this package. Lines likes crystals grow on a computational substrate. A simple perpendicular growth rule creates intricate city-like structures.
\ 
\ The following preferences settings are available:
\ 
\ • Run time sets the time (actually the number of computation cycles) the hack will run for before starting over. Longer run times produce more dense patterns before resetting.
\ 
\ • Number of cracks sets the number of cracks which will be developed at one time.
\ 
\ • Sand density sets the amount of sand to paint each crack with.
\ 
\ j.tarbell June, 2004 / Albuquerque, New Mexico / complexification.net

Inter.Aggregate shows a surface filled with medium to small sized discs. Each disc has a different size and direction, but moves at the same slow rate. We display the aggregate intersections of the disc.
\ 
\ The following preferences settings are available:
\ 
\ • Run time sets the time (actually the number of computation cycles) the hack will run for before starting over. Longer run times produce more dense patterns before resetting.
\ 
\ • Number of discs sets the number of discs moving in the background.
\ 
\ • Disc sizes sets the sizes of the discs.
\ 
\ • Both dimensions determines whether the discs move in any direction, or just horizontally (the default).
\ 
\ • Sand density sets the amount of sand to paint the intersections with.
\ 
\ j.tarbell May, 2004 / Albuquerque, New Mexico / complexification.net

Sand.Traveler is a rendering of 1,000 traveling particles, each in pursuit of another. Over time, patterns of travel are exposed as sweeping paths of color.
\ 
\ The following preferences settings are available:
\ 
\ • Run time sets the time (actually the number of computation cycles) the hack will run for before starting over. Longer run times produce more dense patterns before resetting.
\ 
\ • Use sand painter uses an alternate drawing algorithm.
\ 
\ • Initial velocity sets how fast the travellers move initially.
\ 
\ • Sand density sets the amount of sand to paint with.
\ 
\ j.tarbell May, 2004 / Albuquerque, New Mexico / complexification.net

Guts is a composition of many hundreds of gut instances rendered simultaneously in a radial fashion. The gut is a wandering tube like object. Gross, right?
\ 
\ The following preferences settings are available:
\ 
\ • Run time sets the time (actually the number of computation cycles) the hack will run for before starting over. Longer run times produce more dense patterns before resetting.
\ 
\ j.tarbell July, 2004 / Albuquerque, New Mexico / complexification.net

string-array.name: help_info_texts
string-array.item: There is a discussion board where you can suggest ideas for Substrate, share experiences and thoughts with other users, and generally waffle. Please note that this group is shared with the other Moonblink projects, so mention Substrate when you post:\n\ \n\ • http://groups.google.com/group/moonblink/topics

If you want to report a bug, you can use the Moonblink Issue tracker. Before you post, please look through the existing issues -- including closed issues -- before raising a new one. Your problem may already have been solved.
\ 
\ If you do need to raise a new issue:
\ • The issue tracker is used by a number of projects. Please click on the "Product-" label to set the product you are reporting against. You can also set the other fields as appropriate.
\ • Please tell me what device, and what version of Android, you are using.
\ • If the bug is a crash, then please attach a log if you possibly can. If you don't know how, don't sweat it.
\ 
\ So, the issue tracker is here:
\ 
\ • http://code.google.com/p/moonblink/issues/list
Substrate is an open project, so if you want to join in and make contributions, you can. See the project page for information:\n\ \n\ • http://code.google.com/p/moonblink/wiki/Substrate
